description: What Do You Do, Dear? A little PSA for all the mamas and papas this election season: Today, for the second time in three weeks, I had to stop in the middle of a lesson to talk about respect-- and politics. Why? Because children, little 9-year-old kids, were cracking jokes about the candidates, booing each other, and using words like "sucks" and "liar" and "stupid." Sometimes we don't realize how ugly we sound until our words come flying from the mouths of these babes. Our children are absorbing our vitriol, you guys. They are taking it in and spitting it out-- at each other. So we talked about it. We talked about strong opinions and why it's okay to have them. We talked about how to express opinions in respectful ways. We talked about sharing our opinions at appropriate times (like maybe not in the middle of a lesson about Internet safety). We talked about how hard it is to do this when we see grown-ups on the news and in our communities who maybe aren't sharing opinions in respectful and compassionate ways. So, to all my grown-up peeps, if you (like me) are guilty of letting the language of this election slip into your home, then maybe we need to take a step back. Take a deep breath. Really show our kids what it looks like to disagree without calling names-- to disagree without losing our integrity. Maybe we should turn the news off while we're at it? It's hard (hard for me at least). But we can do hard things. Our kids deserve to see what grown-ups are capable of-- kindness, goodness, gentleness, and self-control. NW Columbus Macaroni Kid

description: Lysa TerKeurst I have some opinions and thoughts. I have a plethora of words that beg to be spoken. And if I‚Äôm not careful those words can be too much.  Unchecked words that come too fast bring with them a rush of trouble. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important for me to consider three things with my words‚Ä¶  1. Listening should take precedence over speaking.  I‚Äôm going to challenge myself to not interrupt. Wait until there is a true pause in the conversation. Truly consider what the other person has said. And then respond with care.  2. Words should be measured.  Just like I consider how a purchase will affect my bank account, I have to consider how words will affect my relationship account. I can do this by thinking about how my words will come across and intentionally asking myself if there are better words that could be used in this situation.  3. Once they are spoken, I can‚Äôt unspeak them.  Once words come out of my mouth I can‚Äôt gather them back in. Now certainly, I can quickly say I‚Äôm sorry. I can ask for forgiveness. I can attempt to make the wrong right. But I can‚Äôt unspeak my words. Hannah Deric Abraham

description: Messy Motherhood "Can you remember the time we took that vacation to a tropical island? We joked and laughed and drank fruity frozen cocktails. I wore a bikini, and we had sex in the middle of the afternoon.  It seems like forever ago. Before my stretch marks and C-section scar. Before I worried all the time about whether our babies were eating enough vegetables and if they would sleep through the night.  I can almost remember the confidence I had. Just yanking off my pool dress. Tossing it on the chair like I never needed it. I cling to that pool dress now. Like my life depends on it, I cling to that dress.
